title: Stanford Newel
text:
Stanford Newel (June 7, 1839 – April 6, 1907) was an American <a href="Attorney%20at%20law%20%28United%20States%29">attorney</a> and <a href="diplomat">diplomat</a> who served as <a href="United%20States%20Ambassador%20to%20the%20Netherlands">United States Ambassador to the Netherlands</a> and <a href="United%20States%20Ambassador%20to%20Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a>.
Early life.
Stanford Newel was born in <a href="Providence%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Providence, Rhode Island</a> on June 7, 1839. When he was 16, his family moved to St. Anthony, <a href="Minnesota">Minnesota</a>, (now part of <a href="Minneapolis%2C%20Minnesota">Minneapolis</a>), and he was a resident of Minnesota for the rest of his life.
Newel graduated from <a href="Yale%20University">Yale University</a> in 1861 and <a href="Harvard%20Law%20School">Harvard Law School</a> in 1864, afterwards practicing law in <a href="St.%20Paul%2C%20Minnesota">St. Paul</a>.
Career.
A <a href="Minnesota%20Republican%20Party">Republican</a>, Newel served as a Delegate to numerous city, county and state conventions. He served as Chairman of the Minnesota Republican Party for six years, and was a Delegate to the Republican National Conventions of <a href="1884%20Republican%20National%20Convention">1884</a> and <a href="1892%20Republican%20National%20Convention">1892</a>.
In 1897 <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="William%20McKinley">William McKinley</a> appointed Newel as Ambassador to the Netherlands, and he served until 1905. During his time in the Netherlands, Newel was a Delegate to the <a href="Hague%20Conventions%20of%201899%20and%201907%23Hague%20Convention%20of%201899">Hague Convention of 1899</a>.
In 1903 Newel was named <a href="United%20States%20Ambassador%20to%20Luxembourg">United States Ambassador to Luxembourg</a>. He was the first individual to hold this position, and served while continuing to carry out his responsibilities as Ambassador to the Netherlands.
Personal life.
After leaving the Netherlands, Newel lived in retirement in St. Paul, where he died on April 6, 1907.
